abstract:
The text describes a plan to expand an existing tag recovery program for salmon and steelhead in the Lower Columbia River system to include Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags in addition to the current Coded Wire Tags (CWT). The necessity of this expansion lies in the increased use of PIT tags, which grew from 20,000 in 1988 to over 2 million in 2009. Currently, only 2% of returning adult salmon and steelhead passing Bonneville Dam are tagged with PITs.

The goal is to create a unified recovery program for all types of tags (PIT and CWT) and marks used in fisheries and escapement programs. The benefits of this expansion include:
1. Providing comprehensive point and interval estimates for recovered PIT and CWT tags by stratum when sample sizes are sufficient.
2. Making the information available to various stakeholders, such as policy makers, planners, managers, and researchers.

This project builds upon the existing framework and infrastructure of the current CWT recovery program, along with other state, federal, and locally funded fisheries and escapement sampling programs coordinated by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW). This approach allows for a seamless integration of PIT tag recoveries into the existing system.

In summary, expanding the current Lower Columbia River CWT recovery program to include PIT tags is necessary due to the growing use of PITs in fish management. By creating a unified tag recovery program, accurate and comprehensive data on both types of tags can be collected and made available to stakeholders, ultimately improving the effectiveness of fish management efforts.

2. Provide accurate point and interval estimates for recovered PIT and CWT tags by stratum when sufficient sample sizes are available.
3. Make this valuable information accessible to various stakeholders, such as policy makers, planners, managers, etc.

This project leverages the existing framework and infrastructure of the current CWT recovery program along with other state, federal, and locally funded fisheries and escapement sampling programs coordinated by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW).
